author: Matthias Bertrand
title: La Vierge pleurait bien des larmes de sang, mais c'était celui d'une autre: un faux miracle qui secoue l'Italie
text:
La Vierge pleurait bien des larmes de sang, mais c’était celui d’une autre: un faux miracle qui secoue l’Italie
Ce n’est pas tous les jours qu’une statue miraculeuse se retrouve dans une affaire de justice, même dans un pays profondément catholique comme l’Italie. Le pays suit de près l’affaire d’une statue de la Vierge Marie qui, selon une mystique autoproclamée nommée Gisella Cardia, pleurait des larmes de sang. Sauf que les analyses ADN ont livré un résultat pour le moins suspect.
Bien sûr, derrière le supposé miracle, il y avait un business, détaille The Guardian. Mme Cardia avait acheté la statue en 2016 sur un site de pèlerinage catholique à Medjugorje, en Bosnie-Herzégovine. Depuis, elle prétendait que la statue lui parlait en plus de verser des larmes de sang. De quoi attirer des pèlerins par centaines vers un petit sanctuaire dressé par la mystique sur une colline de Trevignano Romano, une petite commune du Latium. Contre espèces sonnantes et trébuchantes versées à une association, qui étaient destinées à la mise en place d’un centre pour enfants malades, du moins selon la pieuse dame.
Pieuse, avec un passé de fraudeuse
Pieuse peut-être, mais rusée sûrement ; Gisella Cardia avait déjà eu maille à partir avec la justice pour une affaire de fraude en lien avec une faillite. Et selon l’enquête d’un détective local, la fameuse statue de la vierge pleurait en fait du sang de porc. Une accusation qui a attiré l’attention de la justice locale.
L’Église catholique elle-même, toujours prudente avec les allégations de miracle, s’est penchée sur l’affaire, et a déclaré la dame fraudeuse l’année dernière. Des anciens fidèles ont également porté plainte pour escroquerie contre la mystique autoproclamée. Jusqu’à ce qu’un laboratoire ne délivre son verdict: il y a bien des traces de sang humain sur la statue. Mais c’est celui de Gisella Cardia. Un résultat qui devrait être remis officiellement aux procureurs le 28 février.
“Connaissez-vous l’ADN de la Madone?”
Pourtant, son avocate certifie qu’il n’y a là pas de contradiction avec un véritable miracle, relève le quotidien britannique: “La trace ADN mérite une enquête plus approfondie, nous attendons de savoir s’il s’agit d’un profil unique ou mixte”, a insisté Solange Marchignoli.
Sa cliente a reconnu avoir “embrassé et manipulé la statue”, ce qui expliquerait qu’elle y a laissé des traces. Mais la statue pourrait quand même être l’objet d’une manifestation de la Vierge, pour l’avocate: “Qui peut le dire? Connaissez-vous l’ADN de la Madone?”
En attendant le verdict de la justice après celui de l’Église, Gisella Cardia a quitté Trevignano Romano et demeure introuvable. “Je ne sais pas où elle prie en ce moment, mais je sais avec certitude qu’elle est animée par une foi profonde et qu’elle n’a rien à gagner dans cette affaire”, la défend encore son avocate.
Pour rappel, seul le pape a l’autorité, dans l’Église catholique, d’attester un fait inexpliqué comme véritablement miraculeux. Et le Vatican se fait de plus en plus méfiant dans ses enquêtes.

author: Reuters
title: Deadly Air India crash probe focuses on actions of plane's captain: report - NewsBreak
text: A cockpit recording of dialogue between the two pilots of the Air India flight that crashed last month indicates the captain cut the flow of fuel to the plane’s engines, the Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday. The newspaper cited people familiar with US officials’ early assessment of evidence uncovered in the investigation into the June 12 crash in Ahmedabad, India, that killed 260 people. The first officer, who was flying the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, asked the more experienced captain why he moved the fuel switches to the “cutoff” position seconds after lifting off the runway, the report said. The two pilots involved were Captain Sumeet Sabharwal and First Officer Clive Kunder, who had total flying experience of 15,638 hours and 3,403 hours, respectively. India’s AAIB, Directorate General of Civil Aviation, Ministry of Civil Aviation, Air India and two unions representing Indian pilots did not immediately respond to Reuters’ requests for comment on the Wall Street Journal report. Boeing declined to comment. Countries order airlines to inspect certain Boeing models after devastating Air India crash A preliminary report into the crash released by India’s Aircraft Accident Investigation Bureau (AAIB) on Saturday said the fuel switches had switched from run to cutoff a second apart just after takeoff, but it did not say how they were flipped. Almost immediately after the plane lifted off the ground, closed-circuit TV footage showed a backup energy source called a ram air turbine had deployed, indicating a loss of power from the engines . One pilot was then heard on the cockpit voice recorder asking the other why he cut off the fuel. “The other pilot responded that he did not do so,” the report said. Without fuel flowing to the engines, the London-bound plane began to lose thrust. After reaching a height of 650 feet, the plane began to sink. The fuel switches for both engines were turned back to run, and the airplane automatically tried restarting the engines, the report said. But the plane was too low and too slow to be able to recover, aviation safety expert John Nance told Reuters. Air India CEO hits back after prelim report suggests deadly crash was caused by pilot error The plane clipped some trees and a chimney before crashing in a fireball into a building on a nearby medical college campus, the report said, killing 19 people on the ground and 241 of the 242 on board the 787. In an internal memo on Monday, Air India CEO Campbell Wilson said the preliminary report found no mechanical or maintenance faults and that all required maintenance had been carried out. The AAIB’s preliminary report had no safety recommendations for Boeing or engine manufacturer GE. After the report was released, the US Federal Aviation Administration and Boeing privately issued notifications that the fuel switch locks on Boeing planes are safe, a document seen by Reuters showed and four sources with knowledge of the matter said. The circumstantial evidence increasingly indicates that a crew member flipped the engine fuel switches, Nance said, given there was “no other rationale explanation” that was consistent with the information released to date. CLICK HERE TO SIGN UP FOR OUR MORNING REPORT NEWSLETTER Nonetheless, investigators “still have to dig into all the factors” and rule out other possible contributing factors which would take time, he said. Most air crashes are caused by multiple factors, and under international rules, a final report is expected within a year of an accident. The Air India crash has rekindled debate over adding flight deck cameras, known as cockpit image recorders, on airliners. Nance said investigators likely would have benefited greatly from having video footage of the cockpit during the Air India flight. Air India has faced additional scrutiny on other fronts after the crash. The European Union Aviation Safety Agency said this month it plans to investigate its budget airline , Air India Express, after Reuters reported the carrier did not follow a directive to change engine parts of an Airbus A320 in a timely manner and falsified records to show compliance. author: PODER360
title: Trabalhadores da Boeing nos EUA entram em greve nesta 6ª feira
text:
O sindicato que representa os trabalhadores de fábricas de aviões da Boeing nos Estados Unidos anunciou, na 5ª feira (12.set.2024), o início da greve do setor a partir desta 6ª feira (13.set).
Integrantes da Associação Internacional de Maquinistas e Trabalhadores Aeroespaciais, em Seattle (Washington), votaram na 5ª feira (12.set) para rejeitar uma proposta de aumento dos salários em 25% ao longo de 4 anos e paralisar as atividades nas fábricas.
Formulário de cadastro alertas grátis do Poder360 concordo com os termos da LGPD . Inscreva-se Inscreva-se Segundo a entidade, 94,6% foram contra o acordo e 96% aprovaram a paralisação , bem mais do que o mínimo de 2/3 dos votos exigidos para a medida entra em vigor.
A decisão envolve 33.000 maquinistas da Boeing, a maioria deles no Estado de Washington. Com a greve, a produção de aviões comerciais deve ser interrompida, de acordo com a emissora norte-americana CBS .
Boeing em crise reputacional A greve não afetará os voos, mas colabora para aumentar a crise reputacional em que a Boeing se encontra. A segurança dos aviões 737 Max, os mais vendidos da companhia, está em xeque desde que 2 deles caíram, em 2018 e 2019, matando 346 pessoas.

author: Bhavika Jain
title: Is this village near Mumbai an Islamic State 'liberated zone'? - Times of India
text: Barely 60 kilometres from Mumbai lie the villages of Borivali and Padgha. Surrounded by the slopes of Mahuli Hills, this quaint locality in Bhiwandi taluka in Thane district has for long earned notoriety for being an alleged terror hotbed. And a recent crackdown by the National Investigation Agency (NIA) took it a notch higher.In the early hours of December 9, the NIA busted a ‘terror network’ in Borivali-Padgha. The federal counter-terror agency arrested 15 people for their alleged links with the proscribed Islamic State (also known as Isis).The crackdown was part of simultaneous operations conducted in 44 locations across Maharashtra and neighbouring Karnataka.“NIA investigations have revealed that the accused, all members of Isis Maharashtra module, were operating from Padgha-Borivali, where they had hatched a conspiracy to spread terror and violence across India,” the agency said in a statement.“The arrested accused had self-declared the village of Padgha in rural Thane as a ‘liberated zone’. They were motivating impressionable Muslim youth to relocate to Padgha from their place of residence for strengthening the Padgha base,” the statement read.But this is not the first time that the village has seen such a crackdown. Almost two decades ago, some of its residents were accused of indulging in terrorist acts as well. medium106348945A blast from the pastFive residents of the Muslim-dominated village were convicted in the 2002-03 Mumbai serial blasts case. The key accused, Saquib Nachan, is one of the 15 people arrested during the December 9 raids. He has been named as the kingpin and head of the Islamic State module in Maharashtra. In August this year, Saquib’s son Shamil was arrested in connection with the Isis sleeper cell that was busted by the police in Pune.Saquib has been booked in over a dozen terror cases and convicted twice. In 1997, he was convicted by the Supreme Court for planning terror attacks in India, along with Khalistani terrorists. He was convicted again in 2016 by a Mumbai court under the Arms Act. He served both the sentences and was released in 2017. medium106349118A ‘liberated zone’ The Islamic State and its various offshoots are banned under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967, or the UAPA. According to the US’ Director of National Intelligence, Islamic State is a Salafi-jihadist group that has conducted and inspired terrorist attacks worldwide, resulting in thousands killed or injured.Voice of Hind, a propaganda magazine suspected to be published by the Islamic State a few years ago, appealed to Indian Muslims to “wake up” and fight against the alleged oppression and atrocities meted out to the community.In its statement, the NIA claimed to have recovered a pistol, two air-guns, eight swords or knives, more than ₹68 lakh in cash, 51 Hamas flags, incriminating documents, smartphones and other digital devices, during the raids on December 9.The agency also said that the arrested men, who are in police custody, had self-declared the village of Padgha as a ‘liberated zone’ and as ‘Al Sham’ (an Arabic word used for Levant or greater Syria). They had allegedly motivated impressionable Muslim youth to relocate to Padgha for strengthening the Islamic State's base.The prime accused in the Padgha case, Saquib Nachan, used to administer a 'bayath' (oath of allegiance to the Khalifa of Islamic State) to the persons joining the proscribed organisation, the NIA claimed.Locals, however, deny any such attempts to declare Padgha as a “liberated territory” or asking Muslims to relocate to the area. “Most of the people in the village have been here for generations. We all know each other, people who have relocated are the ones who have found work in the nearby warehouses,” a local says speaking on condition of anonymity.He stresses that the Padgha gram panchayat and all other government offices in the area still retain their names, “Where is the question of declaring the village as ‘Al-Sham’?” he asked. 106351657Other side of the storyVillagers tell TOI+ that police and NIA are telling just one side of the story. They say Padgha finds mention in India’s history for its contribution to the freedom struggle. Village women had then stepped out of their houses during the Swadeshi movement and set afire British goods in Borivali. “That part of the history has been conveniently forgotten,” says another local. Families and friends of the arrested men says that none of them were involved in any illegal activities, let alone terrorism. They also express concerns over the manner in which the village was being linked to terrorist acts repeatedly.The villagers have now appointed a common lawyer to fight their case although it is not clear as to what charges the NIA has pressed against the 15 accused.“Padgha has been given a bad name because of one family, but that doesn’t mean the entire village has criminals. We have had instances of job letters being cancelled when the employer came to know that the person lives in Padgha. Many of our young boys are also struggling to find a match [for marriage]. Why should they be punished?” sayss Ravish Khot, a small-time realtor.“My son [26-year-old Yahya Khot] got married last year and his wife is expecting. Like in most houses of the village that were raided, nothing was found from our house too,” says Khot, who suffered a heart attack at the time of the raid and had to be rushed to a hospital in Bhiwandi. “Besides the men who have been arrested, the NIA officers are calling other people, as young as 14-15 year old, for questioning. Is that even fair?” asks Khot. Families cry foulSitting inside her partially dilapidated house, Rameeza Nachan (not related to Saquib Nachan) says she hasn't seen her two sons – Rafil (21) and Razil (22) since the day they were arrested by the NIA. “I was in Ajmer for a pilgrimage when the raids happened; both my boys were in the house at the time. Had I known this would happen, I would have never left them alone,” says Rameeza.“When I came home, the entire house was in a mess. I still don't know what the central agencies found in my house and arrested my children in such a serious case,” Rameeza wonders. 106349355Her two sons have been the only breadwinners for the family since her husband’s death five months ago. They used to drive a shared taxi on the Padgha-Bhiwandi route to feed the family. “We were waiting for Razil to finish his graduation so that he can look for a good job and earn better. But after this [the raid and arrest by NIA], we don't know what is in store for all of us. I don't even have money to pay for a lawyer,” she says. Claiming that her family has been living in Padgha for several decades now, Rameeza says the entire locality can vouch for the innocence of her family members. She has filed an application in the court, pleading that Razil be allowed to appear for his exam which he had missed due to his father’s death. Abubakar Kunnathpeedikal, father of another accused Munzir Kunnathpeedikal (37), says his son is a hardware engineer and runs his own internet and CCTV camera business. Munzir is married and has three children.“Officers started banging the door in the middle of the night. When I opened the door, they barged in and asked for Munzir. I woke him up and they said they had a search warrant. After searching the house, they took Munzir with them,\" says Abubakar. He shows TOI+ a document in which the officers had written that no item was seized from their house. “My son doesn’t even have an NC (non-cognisable offence) registered against him. Our family has nothing to do with the charges the police have levelled. In fact, Munzir worked on installing the internet line at the Padgha police station and the officers there knew him very well,” says Abubakar.

author: Maria Loreto
title: Harry Potter: All we know about the awaited TV series
text:
By Maria Loreto - New York April 11, 2024 5:24 PM EDT “ Harry Potter ” is back for a new generation of kids. This time, the boy who lived will be appearing on our TV screens, with producers and creators recruiting a new batch of young actors to bring to life the characters and stories we all know and love.
Here’s all we know about the upcoming “Harry Potter” TV series:
RELATED: Michael Gambon, Dumbledore in ‘Harry Potter’ films, has died at 82
7 Hispanic directors you should know about
It will air on Max The Harry Potter series was announced last year, with Max having the streaming rights to it. “This new Max Original series will dive deep into each of the iconic books that fans have continued to enjoy for all of these years,” said Casey Bloys, the Chairman and CEO of HBO & Max Content, at the time. The adaptation promises to be an in depth exploration of the books, and is being mapped out for a 10 year plan, much like the original series of films.
The series is expected to premiere on Max at some point in 2026.
Who is making it? The hiring process for the series showrunner has been long. Deadline reported that a couple of American and British writers are in the mix, including Francesca Gardiner, known for her work in “Succession,” Kathleen Jordan, creator of “Teenage Bounty Hunters,” and Tom Moran, creator of “The Devil’s Hour.” The books’ author, J.K. Rowling, has reportedly been involved in the hiring process.
The final decision is expected to be made in June.
What about actors? Not much is known about the actors that are being cast, only that they’re between the ages of 11 and 12. According to Bloys, casting the talent will occur after a showrunner is hired. “We have been trying to be very close to the vest,” she said recently. “We haven’t gone out to agencies. We have our own internal process where we’ve been thinking about people but we have not wanted to go out into the world.”
Will franchise veterans reappear on the show?
©GettyImages
Emma Watson, Daniel Radcliffe and Rupert Grint Daniel Radcliffe , Rupert Grint and Emma Watson have all gone to develop flourishing careers as actors following their work in the Harry Potter films. If they were to return to the series, it would likely boost its engagement. Still, for the time being, it appears to be unlikely.
“My understanding is that they’re trying to very much start fresh and I’m sure whoever is making them will want to make their own mark on it and probably not want to have to figure out how to get old Harry to cameo in this somewhere,” said Radcliffe to ComicBook.com.

title: New AI model to help prevent power outages
text:
New Delhi: A team of US researchers has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) model that could help electrical grids prevent power outages by automatically rerouting electricity in milliseconds.
The automated system, published online in the journal Nature Communications, is an early example of “self-healing grid” technology, which uses AI to detect and repair problems such as outages and storm-damaged power lines on its own without human intervention.
Researchers from the University of Texas at Dallas demonstrated that their solution can automatically identify alternative routes to transfer electricity to users before an outage occurs. It is because AI has the advantage of speed, the team said. Unlike human-controlled processes that can take minutes to hours, the system can automatically reroute electrical flow in microseconds.
Also Read Sony Pictures Networks India appoints Gaurav Banerjee as MD and CEO “Our goal is to find the optimal path to send power to the majority of users as quickly as possible,” said Dr Jie Zhang, associate professor of mechanical engineering at the Erik Jonsson School of Engineering and Computer Science.
“But more research is needed before this system can be implemented.”
Roshni Anna Jacob, an electrical engineering doctoral student at the varsity, said that electricity blocked due to line faults can be reconfigured using switches and power from available sources nearby, such as from large-scale solar panels or batteries.
The researchers next aim to develop similar technology to repair and restore the grid after a power disruption.
